docs.snippet: A coalition dominated by Marxist parties came to power in Chile last year with only 36.3 per cent of the popular vote -- because the country's democratic forces were divided. Now another South American country with a deeply-rooted democratic...
docs.lead_paragraph: A coalition dominated by Marxist parties came to power in Chile last year with only 36.3 per cent of the popular vote -- because the country's democratic forces were divided. Now another South American country with a deeply-rooted democratic tradition, tiny Uruguay, may be on its way down the same road.
docs.abstract: Ed on upcoming election voices fear that attempt at reelection by Pres Pacheco might prove divisive for dem forces in Uruguay and bring to power Marxist-dominated govt similar to that in Chile; notes that faction of Pacheco's party has already nominated another candidate, J Battle, while all left-wing forces have formed broad coalition which Tupamaros are supporting; also notes that for Pacheco to qualify for another term, voters must 1st approve electoral amendment

headline.main: Elms Wins and Raises Lead In World Snipe Class Sail

docs.snippet: LONDON -- In the near future, The European Football Union, otherwise known as Eufa, will have to pass judgment on the refusal of Ajax of Amsterdam, holder of the European Cup, to go to Montevideo, Uruguay, to contest the intercontinental soccer...
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON -- In the near future, The European Football Union, otherwise known as Eufa, will have to pass judgment on the refusal of Ajax of Amsterdam, holder of the European Cup, to go to Montevideo, Uruguay, to contest the intercontinental soccer championship against Nacional, winner of the South American Cup.
docs.abstract: London sports columnist B Glanville on violence at intercontinental soccer champs

headline.main: The Cup of Horrors; European Soccer Champions Eschew Violence-Ridden Intercontinental Event

byline.original: By BRIAN GLANVILLESpecial to The New York Times

docs.snippet: Under renewed pressure at the United Nations to accept at least a short extension of his term when it expires Dec. 31, Secretary General Thant warned that time was running short for his job to be filled and urged prompt action on a successor.
docs.lead_paragraph: Under renewed pressure at the United Nations to accept at least a short extension of his term when it expires Dec. 31, Secretary General Thant warned that time was running short for his job to be filled and urged prompt action on a successor.
docs.abstract: Min Sena challenges ex-Min Erro to pistol duel after Erro calls him 'coward' in pub; both prove to be poor marksmen but do not schedule another duel

headline.main: Thant Is Firm on Stepping Down

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: Your Oct. 13 editorial "Uruguay: Perils of Division" raises several questions of fact and interpretation. By arguing that the Allende election in Chile and the forthcoming Uruguayan elections can be interpreted as struggles between the "divided...
docs.lead_paragraph: Your Oct. 13 editorial "Uruguay: Perils of Division" raises several questions of fact and interpretation. By arguing that the Allende election in Chile and the forthcoming Uruguayan elections can be interpreted as struggles between the "divided democratic forces" and the radical left, you disguise the issue in both cases -- whether there exist alternatives to continued economic stagnation.
docs.abstract: P M Cohen lr takes issue with facts and interpretation presented in Oct 13 ed on Pres Pacheco's attempt at re-election; says real issue is not struggle between 'divided dem forces' and radical left but whether there exist alternatives to Uruguay's continued econ stagnation; describes reform coalition Frente Amplio as having been formed at initiative of Christian Dems; contends that if Frente succeeds it will be because of inability of traditional parties, Blancos and Colorados, to govern effectively, not because of their internal divs

docs.snippet: Eleven days after a mysterious fire destroyed part of the electrical control system at The Consolidated Edison Company's new nuclear power plant at Indian Point, near Peekskill, workmen and inspectors yesterday were still scrubbing soot from the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Eleven days after a mysterious fire destroyed part of the electrical control system at The Consolidated Edison Company's new nuclear power plant at Indian Point, near Peekskill, workmen and inspectors yesterday were still scrubbing soot from the blackened walls and picking among the charred wires and dismantled components, trying to determine the extent of the damage.
docs.abstract: Damage from Nov 4 fire at Consol Edison Indian Point plant No 2 described; not fully established yet

headline.main: Con Ed Survey in Fire Damage at a Nuclear Plant

docs.snippet: SANT' ANA DO LIVRAMENTO, Brazil, Nov. 12 -- Little Uruguay has gone into the final two weeks of a strong leftist drive in her presidential election campaign, with occasional nervous glances north across the border at huge Brazil, whose military...
docs.lead_paragraph: SANT' ANA DO LIVRAMENTO, Brazil, Nov. 12 -- Little Uruguay has gone into the final two weeks of a strong leftist drive in her presidential election campaign, with occasional nervous glances north across the border at huge Brazil, whose military Government is uncompromisingly hostile to the Marxist left.
docs.abstract: Brazil acts to assure Uruguay against feared invasion if leftist coalition wins upcoming Pres election; cancels mil maneuvers that were scheduled near Brazil-Uruguay border and declares that Brazil has no imperialist goals; Uruguayans' nervousness about leftist drive in campaign linked to Brazil's hostility towards Marxist left

headline.main: Brazil Acts to Assure Uruguay, Nervous if Leftists Win Election

byline.original: By JOSEPH NOVITSKISpecial to The New York Times

docs.snippet: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 20 -- Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba has worn many hats -- literally -- during his extended tour of Chile, but his consistent message to workers, students, peasants and military officers has been a call for revolutionary unity.
docs.lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 20 -- Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba has worn many hats -- literally -- during his extended tour of Chile, but his consistent message to workers, students, peasants and military officers has been a call for revolutionary unity.

headline.main: Castro, on Tour of Chile, Urging Revolutionary Unity; Also Puts on Many Hats and Delights His Admirers
